titleInfo.title: Microtubule Nucleation, Post-Translational Modifications, and Minus-End Maintenance in Drosophila Melanogaster

mods:mods.abstract: Using Drosophila melanogaster as a model, this dissertation explores microtubule dynamics in vivo to understand the mechanisms of microtubule nucleation, post-translational modifications, and minus-end proteins at various microtubule organizing centers (MTOCs). The -Tubulin Ring Complex (-TuRC) is the major microtubule nucleator of eukaryotic cells. Its function is best understood in its essential roles in cell division. The core components of the -TuRC, called Gamma-tubulin Complex Proteins (GCPs, or Gamma-Ring Proteins/Grips in Drosophila), are highly conserved across Eukaryotes. Strikingly, the composition and organization of GCPs in the -TuRC from recent CryoEM structures from various organisms are similar, suggesting the -TuRC is a preferred nucleation method throughout evolution. This dissertation dissects a unique -TuRC in Drosophila comprised of variant GCP paralogs, referred to as t-Grips, and its specialized role in spermiogenesis. We show that t-Grips acquired a unique and distinct function, as replacement of t-Grips with Grips or vice versa is insufficient to rescue mutant phenotypes. Additionally, t-Grips form a complex separate from the canonical -TuRC in the testes. t-Grips are absent from centrosomes but localize to mature sperm tails, where they play a critical role in developing structural resiliency in the specialized mitochondria during spermiogenesis. In the absence of t--TuRCs, mitochondria become fragile and fragment under stress causing sperm tails to break. Tubulin post-translational modifications (PTMs) convey the functional specificity of microtubules by modulating how microtubule-associated proteins (MAPs) interact with microtubules. The complex effects of PTMs on tubulin and microtubule functions have collectively been referred to as the "tubulin code". Our understanding of how TTLL enzymes modify tubulin largely relies on in vitro data. To understand tubulin PTMs in vivo, we have developed a screen to assess which modifying enzymes are vital to various cellular functions in Drosophila. The screen revealed 5 essential TTLL enzymes: TTLL1B, TTLL3B, TTLL4B, TTLL6B, and TTLL12. I further show that TTLL6B is the major glutamylase in the testes and that TTLL4B has a potential novel target. Microtubule minus-end proteins regulate the organization of microtubules in cells. Here we develop a screen by targeting them to the surface of the mitochondria of cultured cells to determine their requirements in organizing MTOCs.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Biomedical Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Timothy L. Megraw, Professor Directing Dissertation; Hong-Guo Yu, University Representative; Yanchang Wang, Committee Member; Robert Tomko, Jr., Committee Member.
